docs.abstract: Elected officials have pushed vocational programs at the expense of the liberal arts. That’s hurting America.
docs.snippet: Elected officials have pushed vocational programs at the expense of the liberal arts. That’s hurting America.
docs.lead_paragraph: Is a university a university without the liberal arts? Marymount University seems to think so. The institution’s trustees voted unanimously in February to eliminate majors in mathematics, art, English, history and philosophy, among other fields. It is the latest in a very long line of defeats for the liberal arts. Between 2013 and 2016, across the United States, 651 foreign language programs were closed, while majors in classics, the arts and religion have frequently been eliminated or, at larger schools, shrunk. The trend extends from small private schools like Marymount to the Ivy League and major public universities, and shows no sign of stopping.

headline.main: Colleges Should Be More Than Just Vocational Schools

docs.abstract: As homelessness overwhelms downtown Phoenix, a small business wonders how long it can hang on.
docs.snippet: As homelessness overwhelms downtown Phoenix, a small business wonders how long it can hang on.
docs.lead_paragraph: Joe Faillace, 69, has been running the sandwich shop Old Station Subs alongside his wife, Debbie, for the last four decades. But as an epidemic of unsheltered homelessness began to overwhelm Phoenix, and many other major American downtowns, the Faillaces have been met with hundreds of people sleeping within a few blocks of Old Station. Many of them were suffering from mental illness or substance abuse, resulting in incidents such as pilfered goods and public masturbation.

headline.main: The Sunday Read: ‘A Sandwich Shop, a Tent City and an American Crisis’

byline.original: By Eli Saslow, Tally Abecassis, Aaron Esposito, John Woo and Sophia Lanman

docs.abstract: Trouble comes when Democrats try to do everything everywhere all at once.
docs.snippet: Trouble comes when Democrats try to do everything everywhere all at once.
docs.lead_paragraph: In February, I visited Tahanan, a building that might be the answer to San Francisco’s homelessness crisis. I left wishing that the answer had been other than what it was.

keywords.name: creative_works
keywords.value: Chip War: The Fight for the World's Most Critical Technology (Book)

byline.original: By Ezra Klein and Janet Delaney

docs.abstract: As a veterinarian, I counseled many people through the end of a beloved pet’s life. But when my cat got sick, it started a whole new journey.
docs.snippet: As a veterinarian, I counseled many people through the end of a beloved pet’s life. But when my cat got sick, it started a whole new journey.
docs.lead_paragraph: Marula was an orange kitty, a purr machine with multiple birth defects, so he was the perfect cat to be a veterinarian’s companion. He purred against my belly when I was pregnant and, years later, he never missed story time, seeming to read the book from one side of me while my son sat on the other. “Did you know your cat is limping?” new visitors to my home often asked with alarm. I’d point out the cat’s shortened leg and funky paw and reassure them that, despite his awkward gait, he got around just fine.

headline.main: Ending Your Pet’s Life Was the Right Decision. So Why Do You Feel So Guilty?

docs.abstract: Known for her quiet pragmatism, Tsai Ing-wen has ushered in a new era of American cooperation as worries about Chinese aggression rise.
docs.snippet: Known for her quiet pragmatism, Tsai Ing-wen has ushered in a new era of American cooperation as worries about Chinese aggression rise.
docs.lead_paragraph: In an island renowned for boisterous politics, Taiwan President Tsai Ing-wen is an improbable leader.

headline.main: ‘On a Tightrope’: How Taiwan’s President Navigated the U.S. and China

byline.original: By John Liu, Amy Chang Chien, Chris Horton and Paul Mozur

docs.abstract: Seizing on a powerful motivator for their party, Democratic candidates for municipal offices have put Republicans on their heels. “I’m running for mayor, I’m not debating abortion,” one said.
docs.snippet: Seizing on a powerful motivator for their party, Democratic candidates for municipal offices have put Republicans on their heels. “I’m running for mayor, I’m not debating abortion,” one said.
docs.lead_paragraph: GREEN BAY, Wis. — Eric Genrich is running a full-throated campaign in support of abortion rights, reminding voters of his position at every turn and hammering his anti-abortion opponent in television ads. At a recent event, he featured an obstetrician who now commutes to a state where abortion is legal to treat patients and a local woman who traveled to Colorado to terminate a nonviable pregnancy.

headline.main: Democrats Run on Abortion, Even for Offices With Little Say on the Issue

docs.abstract: Federal officials are investigating the railroad’s safety practices and culture after the derailment in East Palestine, Ohio, and worker deaths.
docs.snippet: Federal officials are investigating the railroad’s safety practices and culture after the derailment in East Palestine, Ohio, and worker deaths.
docs.lead_paragraph: Norfolk Southern once had so few accidents and injuries that it won the rail industry’s prestigious E.H. Harriman safety award for 23 years in a row until it was retired in 2012. But in the last decade, the company has gone from an industry leader to a laggard.

headline.main: Norfolk Southern’s Push for Profits Compromised Safety, Workers Say

docs.abstract: Linda Pagan, who runs a popular hat shop in SoHo, likes to stroll and visit neighborhood spots like Fanelli Cafe and Film Forum.
docs.snippet: Linda Pagan, who runs a popular hat shop in SoHo, likes to stroll and visit neighborhood spots like Fanelli Cafe and Film Forum.
docs.lead_paragraph: “The right hat is an expression of your personality,” said Linda Pagan, who owns The Hat Shop NYC. “You are never alone when you wear a hat — wearing one is like walking a dog but without all the work; people will always stop and talk to you.”

headline.main: How a Milliner Spends Her Sundays
headline.print_headline: Atop Her List, Taking the Hat for a Walk

docs.abstract: More than 280,000 Ukrainians have escaped the war through a program meant to resettle them into the homes of Americans. But not everyone has found a safe or welcoming place to stay.
docs.snippet: More than 280,000 Ukrainians have escaped the war through a program meant to resettle them into the homes of Americans. But not everyone has found a safe or welcoming place to stay.
docs.lead_paragraph: For weeks, Stanislav Holotiuk had been searching for someone to help him flee the war in Ukraine and sponsor his resettlement in the United States.

headline.main: These Ukrainians Arrived Under a Biden Program. They Ended Up Homeless.

docs.abstract: In a new book, Timothy Egan traces the Klan’s expansion in the 1920s across American political and civic life. Then its leader, David C. Stephenson, committed murder.
docs.snippet: In a new book, Timothy Egan traces the Klan’s expansion in the 1920s across American political and civic life. Then its leader, David C. Stephenson, committed murder.
docs.lead_paragraph: The scene, in some ways, could not have been more commonplace. On July 4, 1923, in a creekside park in Kokomo, Ind., families celebrated Independence Day with flags and bunting, watermelon and pie, patriotic songs, a parade. Commonplace — except that these families, many thousands in number, wore the white hoods and robes of the Ku Klux Klan. Banners insisted that “America is for Americans”; floats portrayed Klansmen defending women from Black people and Catholics. As the day’s featured speaker — David C. Stephenson, Grand Dragon of the Realm of Indiana — stepped out of the rear cockpit of a Klan-branded biplane, members of the crowd dropped to their knees and, in rapture, reached out their arms. “My worthy subjects,” Stephenson exulted.

headline.main: The Rise and Fall of a Grand Dragon of the Ku Klux Klan

keywords.name: creative_works
keywords.value: A Fever in the Heartland: The Ku Klux Klan's Plot to Take Over America, and the Woman Who Stopped Them (Book)
